newsitem.title: USA: Venezuelan oil crucial to Americas - U.S. official.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelan oil crucial to Americas - U.S. official.

text.p: U.S. relations with Venezuela and development of its energy sector are crucial to the security of the Western Hemisphere, a senior White House official said on Monday.

Highlighting growing energy demand and the success last week of Venezuela's third round of bids for contracts to revive ageing oil fields, Thomas "Mack" McLarty, U.S. special envoy for the Americas, said the opening of Venezuela's oil sector was an important example for the rest of Latin America.

"If we are to meet our commitments to the hemisphere, if democracy is to deliver, we simply must work together ... to find market-based solutions to meet our energy needs," he said at a luncheon sponsored by the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
"It is not just a matter of convenience. It is a matter of United States and hemispheric security," he said.

McLarty, an adviser to President Bill Clinton, urged Venezuela to reach an agreement with the United States on bilateral tax and investment treaties, under negotiation for some time, which he said would help expand the flow of capital to Venezuela and improve investor confidence.

"These agreements I think will remove existing tax disincentives and provide investors guaranteed access to international arbitration," he said. "Our partnership with Venezuela and with other democratic nations of the Americas ... is a key to our long-term prosperity and the very well-being of the Americas."

McLarty reiterated the administration's commitment to submitting legislation to Congress in September to move U.S. trade negotiations with other countries onto a fast track, eliminating fear that treaties might be changed by Congress.
"That's a specific, a public timeline to which we can and should be held accountable," he said, adding that "we are beginning to build some consensus" in Congress in favour of the legislation.
